segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Accounts Rename guest account security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Accounts Rename guest account security policy setting.

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Accounts: Rename guest account security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Accounts: Rename guest account security policy setting.

segment.source: The Accounts: Rename guest account policy setting determines whether a different account name is associated with the security identifier (SID) for the Guest account.
segment.target: The Accounts: Rename guest account policy setting determines whether a different account name is associated with the security identifier (SID) for the Guest account.

segment.source: For devices in unsecured locations, renaming the account makes it more difficult for unauthorized users to guess it.
segment.target: For devices in unsecured locations, renaming the account makes it more difficult for unauthorized users to guess it.

segment.source: For computers in secured or trusted locations, keeping the name of the account as Guest provides consistency among devices
segment.target: For computers in secured or trusted locations, keeping the name of the account as Guest provides consistency among devices

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: This policy setting can be configured by using the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) to be distributed through Group Policy Objects (GPOs).
segment.target: This policy setting can be configured by using the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) to be distributed through Group Policy Objects (GPOs).

segment.source: If this policy is not contained in a distributed GPO, this policy can be configured on the local device by using the Local Security Policy snap-in.
segment.target: If this policy is not contained in a distributed GPO, this policy can be configured on the local device by using the Local Security Policy snap-in.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: The guest account exists in all Windows server and client operating system versions beginning with Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP Professional.
segment.target: The guest account exists in all Windows server and client operating system versions beginning with Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP Professional.

segment.source: Because the account name is well known, it provides a vector for a malicious user to get access to network resources and attempt to elevate privileges or install software that could be used for a later attack on your system.
segment.target: Because the account name is well known, it provides a vector for a malicious user to get access to network resources and attempt to elevate privileges or install software that could be used for a later attack on your system.

segment.source: Specify a new name in the Accounts: Rename guest account setting to rename the Guest account.
segment.target: Specify a new name in the Accounts: Rename guest account setting to rename the Guest account.

segment.source: If you rename this account, it is slightly more difficult for unauthorized persons to guess this privileged user name and password combination.
segment.target: If you rename this account, it is slightly more difficult for unauthorized persons to guess this privileged user name and password combination.

segment.source: There should be little impact because the Guest account is disabled by default in Windows 2000 Server, Windows Server 2003, and Windows XP.
segment.target: There should be little impact because the Guest account is disabled by default in Windows 2000 Server, Windows Server 2003, and Windows XP.

segment.source: For later operating systems, the policy is enabled with Guest as the default.
segment.target: For later operating systems, the policy is enabled with Guest as the default.
